posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
Hi CD , In the spring I gradated from high school and from my Robotics team frc2877 .  As part of LigerBots I acquired hundreds of hours of experience in Onshape making all sorts of robot related things as the team as a designer since 2021 and the Design Lead for the 2024 season. I also designed various things for 3d printing for both personal and work related. I am now in my first week of college as a mechanical engineering student at Wentworth Institute of Technology in Boston. I have some personal projects that I could relatively easily model in Onshape but I want to practice using Solidworks because that is what my college uses.

I am wondering if people have any tips or resources for someone coming from Onshape to Solidworks. I have seen there are a lot of resources for people going to Onshape from Solidworks but nothing the other way around. I have heard that “it is just button are in different places” but on my first poke around there seem to be key differences in the basic workflow(sketches) and often used hotkeys. I have not dug in deep at all and if this is just something that I will figure out after a few hours of use just let me know. But any advice and tips would be appreciated to help transition with less frustration.

2024 Shooter image 1327×631 70.1 KB Outreach Robot Intake+transfer image 1053×784 67.7 KB Mini Robot CAD project image 993×790 102 KB Hydrogen powered car + parts library of a summer program I taught at image 778×683 63.5 KB Camera Mount for my 3D-Printer image 1565×630 70 KB

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: I’m currently in the same situation as you. I’ve found that there’s a lot that’s different, but the fundamentals of parametric CAD are the same. I’d recommend finding and going through a Solidworks beginner’s guide. A lot of it is just breaking muscle memory and getting used to the different methods of using relations, mates, etc.

posts.name: Erik Boyle
posts.cooked:
The second CAD program you learn is often the hardest. You’re at the point where you have to break habits and assumptions and you aren’t used to the things that often differ between programs. Don’t beat yourself up over the difficulty and just keep at it.

SolidWorks does not have a good hotkey setup by default. Head over to Tools > Customize > Keyboard to configure it how you want. You can also completely customize the toolbar layout and appearance from the same window. Spend some time getting both of these how you like them.

Don’t mind the fact that the default feature tree elements are in German. Corporate templates and all that…

Screenshot 2024-09-06 120408 1920×1040 202 KB

Screenshot 2024-09-06 120408 1920×1040 202 KB

Screenshot 2024-09-06 120408 1920×1040 202 KB

Yes, I have toolbars on all four sides of the window.

ElliotS:

PS If there are any cool features that Solidworks has that Onshape does not let me know.

Here are a few bits and bobs that come to mind:

It’s not exactly a feature , but really try to get comfortable with all of SolidWorks’ options for mates, including the Advanced and Mechanical tabs. In particular, options like Symmetric, Width, and Slot don’t have exact one-to-one equivalents in Onshape but are frequently extremely useful.

SolidWorks’ Mirror Components is very featureful. It gives you the ability to control instance-by-instance which items get new mirrored configurations and which can be reused by being rotated in the proper orientation. It can be easy to miss because that functionality is hidden behind a next page arrow in the top right corner of the PropertyManager pane when the feature is active.

A general word of advice: there are a lot of features buried in the Insert dropdown above the ribbon that I often forget about. Check there whenever you need to do something special.

I would encourage anyone using Onshape to (at least temporarily) switch your mouse controls to the SolidWorks layout. This is one of the alternatives you can select under My Account > Preferences > Mouse Controls. Not only do I actually like it better on its own merits, it will give you a slightly easier transition later if you (as many aspiring engineers do) end up having to learn SolidWorks in college. (In SolidWorks, right-click-and-drag is used to quick snap to standard views rather than rotate.) You can also check the box for “Set default rotation behavior to constrained rotate,” which is, in my opinion, a huge QoL improvement that is far too buried. In SolidWorks, the same option is enabled with Right Click in whitespace > Rotate About Scene Floor.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads

posts.custom_user_title: Somewhere between Thunderstruck and Country Roads

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked:
Here are a couple BIG takeaways coming from an engineer that uses Solidworks at work and Onshape at robotics:

File Structure

Onshape is neat because everything is in the cloud, with all of the benefits that brings

Solidworks is a more standard software that uses local files on your computer

These files include Part, Assembly, and Drawing files

These files behave differently than Onshape does, which I get into more below

Saving Work

One strong downside to Solidworks is that it relies on manual saving of work just like any other file-based software

There is a periodic auto-save functionality and reminders to save your work, but it is definitely not as clean and reliable as the Onshape method of saving every single action taken in the document no matter what

At some point, you will almost certainly lose some work in Solidworks due to a crash after having not saved for a while

I’m sorry

Mates

Mates are a contentious topic between Onshape and most other CAD programs

I personally prefer Solidworks Mates from an ease of use perspective, but there are legitimate reasons for the Onshape strategy

In Onshape, you only apply one mate between two parts, and that mate handles eliminating all degrees of freedom (i.e. Fastened Mate), except the ones you intend to leave free (all the others)

In Solidworks, each mate eliminates a certain number and type of degrees of freedom, and you will almost always require 2 or 3 mates to fully constrain a part

The “lock” mate does maintain orientation and position between two parts with one mate, but it is rarely used

Groups (Or Lack Thereof)

That “lock” mate may sound a lot like the “group and fix” strategy often used in Onshape

This strategy is not great for Solidworks, mainly because it does not have the functionality of Part Studios to maintain parametric relationships for the locations and orientations between parts

In Onshape, you can insert a collection of parts from a Part Studio, then group them together and fix or mate one of them in the Assembly

When you then change the part studio, the locations of all of those parts relative to each other will also update in the Assembly

There is no practical way to mimic this in Solidworks, so instead you are always expected to mate each part in a way that restricts all degrees of freedom that you don’t want to remain for mechanical purposes (linear sliding, rotation, etc.) After talking this through with our CAD admin at work, Multi-Body Parts can do this sort of this in Solidworks. However, the process for making Solidworks mimic the complete Onshape functionality has a lot more overhead to get right.

For this reason, the “lock” mate is seldom used in Solidworks except by people who want their assemblies break in weird ways

Multi-Body Parts

You may have heard that you have to have a separate file for each different part in Solidworks

For many users and companies, this IS how it works, and designing this way makes inter-part parametric relationships effectively impossible

However, Solidworks has two features that allow it to operate more like Onshape

In Solidworks Part files, you can design multiple bodies just like you can in Onshape Part Studios

These are called “Multi-Body Parts”

One downside is that you can’t insert a subset of the total bodies in a Multi-Body Part like you can when inserting from a Part Studio to an Assembly

You can get around this by creating multiple configurations of a Multi-Body Part with different bodies deleted, but this is cumbersome and I have never had a reason to do it this way

Also, some modeling tools in Solidworks are restricted to only modifying a single body, like the fillet and chamfer tools

Virtual Parts

The other way to create multiple Parts at once are Virtual Parts, which are parts that exist only in an Assembly file instead of having their own Part file

These are useful when developing your ideas, because creating a Virtual Part is fast and doesn’t clutter up your file structure while you are unsure of the exact Part files your Assembly will need

In Assemblies, there are certain “Assembly Features” you can apply which are like Part Features but existing solely in the Assembly file

This is a useful tool to get similar inter-part parametric relationships to what you can get with Onshape Part Studios

However, because most companies want to create a released version (also called a “Revision” or “Rev”) of specific part files that will not change, Assembly Features are not always a great choice.

If some of the features of a part are actually in an assembly and not the part file itself, then that part file can’t be used for revisioning, which makes official product releases much more complicated

In general, Multi-Body Parts, Virtual Parts, and Assembly Features are all inconvenient when working with a file management tool

Collaboration

This is one of the ways that Onshape really kills Solidworks

Solidworks has no way for different people to effectively make changes to the same file at the same time.

Instead, if you need to collaborate with others, a PDM (Product Data Management) system is used

PDM usually involves keeping a save of each “version” of a file

To make any change to the file, you must make a new version by first “checking out” the file

This tells other users that the file is being edited and prevents them from also checking it out

Once you are done making changes, you then “check in” the file to save a new version to your organizations network drive

This leads to a lot of room for problems, because unlike Onshape, the version history only has snapshots of the history only has snapshots of the changes to the part

If the user checked in a particular version doesn’t give good notes of what they changed, it can be very difficult to understand exactly what happened to the file

In summary, there are definitely a lot of differences that can trip users up when going from Onshape to Solidworks. I might even characterize that switch as harder than going in the other direction. However, Solidworks is still a capable CAD program. Given that it is by far the most common program used by small- and medium-sized companies, it is probably for the better than you are going to make this transition in a learning environment. Good luck!

posts.name: Brandon
posts.cooked:
As someone who’s only used SolidWorks and isn’t familiar with Onshape at all, the comparisons here are really nice and helps me understand a bit better how Onshape actually works.

Just to add on to the point on assembly features, there’s actually an option to “propagate feature to parts” so that the feature shows up in all parts that it affects. We’ll probably mainly be using assembly hole wizards to place the majority of screw holes in the future.

Also, virtual parts in assemblies can be saved as external files so that they exist in your file structure, just with the external relations already there. I’ve found this feature to be pretty useful when trying to work in a top-down workflow in SolidWorks.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
Path length dimensions are great for belts.

Multibody parts are great, definitely the easiest way to ‘think’ in CAD. Just make sure to uncheck ‘Merge Results’ when you want a new body.

You can setup a common parts library in a folder by going to System Options → File Locations → Design Library and adding that folder. This lets you pull parts in from the folder you setup by going to the Design Library Taskpane tab on the upper right. There’s a bunch of other stuff to setup in file locations that can be helpful like templates.

Configurations exist - they’re a bit clunky. I mostly see these used for lengths / single dimension variation.

On a daily basis I use Creo and NX at work (mergers led to legacy CAD on various projects being in different platforms) and Solidworks for FRC . I don’t recommend doing this, but it has helped to get modelling experience in a variety of other CAD platforms since the mindset / workflow can be very different and you never know where you’ll end up working. Switching between them is super clunky though - I push a lot of wrong hotkeys.

kitare102:

There is no practical way to mimic this in Solidworks, so instead you are always expected to mate each part in a way that restricts all degrees of freedom that you don’t want to remain for mechanical purposes (linear sliding, rotation, etc.)

I haven’t used Onshape extensively, but this sounds a lot like the make assembly flexible /rigid feature. Right click on a subassembly and you can lock it’s components together or make them flexible relative to each other.

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked:
Mike_Schreiber:

I haven’t used Onshape extensively, but this sounds a lot like the make assembly flexible /rigid feature. Right click on a subassembly and you can lock it’s components together or make them flexible relative to each other.

That’s another difference between the two programs. In Solidworks, when you bring an assembly into another assembly, it comes in “rigid” by default. This means it is static and has none of it’s degrees of freedom. Making it “flexible” recovers those degrees of freedom. This is different than Onshape, where bringing an assembly into another assembly retains the degrees of freedom by default (I’m not actually sure if you can make an assembly rigid in Onshape, per se)

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked:
I haven’t used Solidworks extensively since 2015 and haven’t touched it in about 5 years, so my information may be a bit out dated.

Without the online based file management, a really useful tool that I remember was the “Pack and Go” function. It allows you to gather all the files (parts, sub-assemblies, drawings, etc) related to the assembly into a single folder. This is important if you need to share the files with professor, or just can’t find all your files (as Solidworks lets you save files in any folder from what i remember).

A big one from my time using it was to save and save often, because Solidworks will inevitably crash when you don’t and you will lose hours of work.

In general, learning a new CAD system really helps you learn how well you understand Parametric modeling as a whole. Part of the reason I like OnShape for FRC is that it isn’t an industry standard yet like Solidworks and Creo, so when you do learn it in school you know how to switch between programs, and can more easily transition to another program when the time comes. So far within FRC , college, and professionally, I’ve used Solidworks, Creo/Pro-E, SolidEdge, and Onshape.

posts.name: NatsirtD
posts.cooked:
kitare102:

(I’m not actually sure if you can make an assembly rigid in Onshape, per se)

You can use a “Group” mate on a subassembly once you’ve inserted it into a higher-level assembly.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
kitare102:

In Solidworks Part files, you can design multiple bodies just like you can in Onshape Part Studios

These are called “Multi-Body Parts”

One downside is that you can’t insert a subset of the total bodies in a Multi-Body Part like you can when inserting from a Part Studio to an Assembly

You can get around this by creating multiple configurations of a Multi-Body Part with different bodies deleted, but this is cumbersome and I have never had a reason to do it this way

You can also make a master part that is multibody but then create a linked part that contains a copy of one of the bodies as a base feature.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
Ekcrbe:

I would encourage anyone using Onshape to (at least temporarily) switch your mouse controls to the SolidWorks layout.

Thanks a ton for the tip! I have started doing this and it was funky for the first 5min bot became easier as I know the rest of the software. It kind of acted as a ice breaker to start trying this different way of doing things.
